Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Story: I stared at my calendar, feeling the familiar tug of anxiety. Our weekly team meeting was scheduled for Thursday afternoon, the same time I’d promised to help my son practice his Torah portion for his upcoming bar mitzvah. As a colleague, I was expected to be present, contribute ideas, and show my commitment to the team—even if the meeting would be recorded. But as a Jewish parent, I felt a deep responsibility to guide my son, to pass on our traditions and ensure he felt confident and prepared for this milestone. My manager had already commented on the importance of everyone being present, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. At the same time, my son’s nervous eyes reminded me how much he needed my support. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each pulling me in a different direction. I sat at my desk, torn, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting someone down.
